8 corn tortillas, warmed (if your tortillas are very thin, double them up for the tacos)

Crumbled Cotija cheese for serving

Crema Mexicana (Mexican cream) or sour cream for serving

Set the poblanos over an open flame on a stove burner and char on all sides, turning them with metal tongs, until the skins are blistered and blackened. (Alternatively, preheat the broiler. Place the poblanos in a broiler pan and position it 2 to 3 inches from the heating element. Char the poblanos on all sides, turning once or twice until the skins are blackened, 5 to 10 minutes.) Place the poblanos in a plastic bag (or a bowl fitted with a lid), seal, and let them steam for 15 to 20 minutes.

Meanwhile, prepare the squash blossoms. Detach the blossoms from the squash and rinse under running water to wash away any bugs that might be lingering inside. Thoroughly pat dry with a towel. (Some people remove the pistils from the centers, but they’re completely edible and have a pleasant texture akin to button mushrooms; I always keep mine intact.) Slice the blossoms in half lengthwise and set aside. Thinly slice the squash and set them aside separately from the blossoms.

Remove the poblanos from the plastic bag and trim the stems. Discard the seeds, peel the skins (they should lift off easily with your fingers), and slice the poblanos into 1/4-inch-wide strips. Set aside.

Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat and drizzle in the oil. Add the onion and garlic and cook until the onion starts to turn translucent, 2 to 3 minutes. Add the squash and cook until tender, about 3 minutes. Add the squash blossoms and sprinkle the salt and pepper on top. Cook until the blossoms are wilted, about 3 minutes.

To assemble the tacos, fill each tortilla with an equal heaping of the poblanos and the squash mixture. Serve with a sprinkle of crumbled Cotija and a drizzle of crema Mexicana.

cook’s note

Squash blossoms appear at farmers’ markets and Mexican markets all summer. If you can’t find female blossoms with baby squash attached, use about 1 heaping cup each of male blossoms (halved lengthwise) and tender squash (finely chopped).

zucchini noodles
WITH ROASTED TOMATOES, PESTO, AND PINE NUTS

These zucchini noodles (zoodles?) are like pasta in disguise, and that’s what I love about them. They’re every bit as fun to twirl around a fork and they play well with pesto, but they leave you with none of that heavy, bloated feeling after a heaping plateful. Since the zucchini brings its own subtle flavor to the table, no heavy sauce is needed for this “pasta” dish either. For a bona fide noodle fiend like myself, I can tell you that I almost don’t miss real noodles after this.

Try it with my Tomato Leaf Pesto (page 35) for a more classic pesto flavor, or gather up your odds and ends to make my Kale Stem Pesto (page 58), which adds a bright, lemony note to this dish.

MAKES 4 SERVINGS

1 1/4 pounds cherry tomatoes, halved

3 garlic cloves, sliced

3 tablespoons olive oil

A few pinches of kosher salt

A few grinds of black pepper

3 rosemary sprigs

3 thyme sprigs

2 pounds zucchini, julienned

1/2 cup pesto (homemade or store-bought)

1/4 cup toasted pine nuts

Shaved Parmesan cheese for serving

Preheat the oven to 325°F.

In a large bowl, toss the tomatoes with the garlic, oil, salt, and pepper until evenly coated. Spread the tomatoes across a large rimmed baking sheet in a single layer, cut sides up, and scatter the rosemary and thyme on top. Roast for about 1 hour until the tomatoes are softened and shriveled. Discard the dried herbs.

In a large sauté pan over medium-high heat, combine the zucchini and pesto and heat through for about 2 minutes.

To serve, divide the zucchini among four plates. Top each plate with a generous heap of roasted tomatoes (including all the juices), a spoonful of pine nuts, and some shaved Parmesan. Serve warm or at room temperature.

PREPARATION TIP

To get the most out of your zucchini, run the julienne peeler down its length, spin the zucchini a bit, then peel it again. Move around the zucchini in a circle and make even julienne cuts until you reach the soft and seedy core (but don’t discard the core, chop it up into a soup or sauté later). Larger zucchini will give you longer, more noodle-like strands, so this is an ideal way to use up any overgrown zucchini from your garden or CSA box. Now, if you have a monstrous zucchini and just the thought of peeling it makes you tired, a vegetable spiral slicer is a handy gadget to have. You’ll be cranking out mounds of curly noodles in mere minutes.

BOTTOM-OF-THE-BOX
bibimbap

Bibimbap—or b-bap, as I like to call it—is a classic Korean rice bowl. You may have seen it served in Korean restaurants in a piping-hot, heavy stone bowl with a raw egg cracked into it. That version, dolsot bibimbap, uses a stone bowl so hot it sizzles everything that touches it, including the rice and the egg. I don’t get that fancy here, but I do serve my b-bap with the signature red sauce that coats all the rice, the vegetables, the egg—everything, really, since the word bibimbap means “mixing rice,” and the only proper way to eat it is to mix it all up with chopsticks before you dive in!

I keep my b-bap simple and use whatever I can find in the kitchen. This is a good way to use up excess squash from your CSA box, leftover carrots or greens, an opened bag of sprouts, a mushroom or two—anything that might go bad soon. I like a combination of seasoned spinach, sautéed vegetables, and fresh sprouts with a sunny-side-up egg. The runny yolk is essential for bringing all the ingredients together in the bowl. If you plan ahead, I highly recommend making and adding some Quick-Pickled Sweet ’n’ Spicy Radish Pods (page 150) to the bowl, too. (Try it with radishes if you don’t have radish pods.)

MAKES 4 SERVINGS

for the sauce

1/4 cup gochujang (Korean red pepper paste, see sidebar)

2 tablespoons hot water

1 tablespoon rice vinegar

1 tablespoon sesame oil

1 tablespoon toasted sesame seeds

2 garlic cloves, minced

for the rice

2 cups uncooked white rice, rinsed

4 cups water

for the bibimbap

8 cups packed spinach

1 tablespoon sesame oil

1 teaspoon toasted sesame seeds

3 tablespoons olive oil, divided

2 zucchini, thinly sliced

2 carrots, cut into 3-inch matchsticks

1 cup packed pea sprouts

4 eggs

To make the sauce, combine all of its ingredients in a small bowl and set aside.

To make the rice, bring the rice and the water to a boil in a medium saucepan. Reduce the heat, cover, and simmer until the water is absorbed and the rice is cooked through, about 25 minutes.

Meanwhile, bring another medium saucepan of salted water to a boil. Blanch the spinach for 1 minute, then drain and thoroughly squeeze out all the liquid. Gather the spinach into a clump and coarsely chop. Transfer the spinach to a large platter, then drizzle the sesame oil and scatter the sesame seeds on top.

Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat and add 1 tablespoon of the olive oil. Stir in the zucchini and cook until tender, about 3 minutes. Transfer the zucchini to the same platter as the spinach.

In the same skillet over medium-high heat, add 1 tablespoon of the olive oil, stir in the carrots, and cook for about 5 minutes until tender. Transfer the carrots to the platter.

Divide the rice among four bowls and arrange the spinach, zucchini, carrots, and pea sprouts on top of the rice.

Reheat the same skillet over medium-high heat and add the remaining 1 tablespoon of olive oil, swirling it around to coat the surface. Crack the eggs into the skillet, making sure the whites don’t run into each other. (If your skillet won’t fit all the eggs at once, fry them in batches.) Cover and reduce the heat to low. Cook until the whites are set and the edges start to brown, about 5 minutes. Top each bowl with a fried egg and serve with a few spoonfuls of sauce to taste.

A PASTE IS NOT A POWDER

Gochujang is a thick and concentrated red pepper paste, typically sold in small tubs or jars at the Korean market. It’s rich and spicy with undertones of sweet, a fermented product made from red chiles, glutinous rice, and fermented soybeans—not to be confused with gochugaru, the red pepper powder used in kimchi (like my Watermelon Rind Kimchi, page 177). The two are not interchangeable, as they have distinctive flavor profiles.

drunken pumpkin chili

Don’t be intimidated by the long list of ingredients here. This is a “dump it and forget it” kind of recipe, the perfect one-pot meal to please and feed a crowd when you’re tucked away in a mountain cabin and everyone is starving after a day on the slopes. I guarantee that as soon as the first mouthwatering smells of slow-cooked pork and spicy, smoky chiles start wafting through the air, your friends will let you have first tracks the next morning.

Despite the name, neither the pumpkin nor the beer will get you drunk, but I do recommend a very dark beer (the darker the better) for added richness. Try a brown ale or a stout.

MAKES 10 TO 12 SERVINGS

2 tablespoons olive oil

3 pounds boneless pork shoulder, trimmed and cut into 1-inch pieces

2 yellow onions, chopped

6 garlic cloves, chopped

2 bell peppers, chopped

2 Anaheim chiles, chopped

1 poblano chile, chopped

1 habanero chile, minced

3 chipotle chiles canned in adobo sauce, chopped

3 cups diced pumpkin

2 cups sweet corn kernels

2 (15-ounce) cans kidney beans, drained and rinsed

1 (28-ounce) can crushed tomatoes, undrained

1 (6-ounce) can tomato paste

1 (12-ounce) bottle dark beer

1 cup strong brewed black coffee

4 cups chicken broth

1 tablespoon ground cumin

1 tablespoon dried oregano

1/4 cup packed brown sugar

Sour cream for serving

Chopped scallions for serving

Shredded cheddar, Monterey jack, or Colby cheese for serving

Heat a large pot over medium-high heat. Drizzle in the oil and add the pork shoulder, stirring periodically until the pork is pinkish-brown on all sides, about 10 minutes. Add the onions and garlic, and cook for 2 to 3 minutes until the onions start to turn translucent. Add all the bell and chile peppers and cook for another 5 minutes. Add the pumpkin, corn, 1 can of kidney beans, crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, beer, coffee, and broth. Stir in the cumin, oregano, and sugar, then bring the pot to a boil.

Once the chili reaches a continuous boil, reduce the heat and simmer uncovered for 1 hour, giving it an occasional stir to make sure the ingredients are well combined. Add the remaining 1 can of kidney beans and continue to simmer for 1 hour more. Serve with a dollop of sour cream, a spoonful of chopped scallions, and a handful of shredded cheese on top.

CHILE PEPPER PRIMER

What I love most about this dish is the way you can personalize it to make your own signature chili. You can use another orange-fleshed winter squash in place of the pumpkin, simmer other cuts of meat, omit the corn, add some carrots; but whatever you do, do not skimp on the chiles. After all, this is pumpkin chili, not pumpkin stew.

The variety of chile peppers used in this recipe offers a complexity in flavor you can’t get from simply using chili powder, a common ingredient in many chili recipes. The store-bought powdered version is never as balanced or rich as real chiles are. First, we have a layer of sweetness from fresh Anaheim chiles, the mildest of the peppers. Then, we have a rich and fruity note from the poblano, heat from the habanero, and smokiness from the chipotles in adobo sauce. If you’re sensitive to spice, you can substitute a cayenne pepper (medium hot) or serrano pepper (least hot) for the habanero.

When you’re out shopping, keep in mind that an Anaheim chile is sometimes called a New Mexico chile or California chile. The young pepper is green and gradually matures into red, at which point it’s called a chile colorado. To make matters even more confusing, many American grocers sometimes mislabel poblano chiles as pasilla chiles, even though true pasillas are actually the dried form of chilaca chiles. If you are sourcing these chiles from a grocer, look for a fresh, wide, dark green pepper.

autumn acorn squash
STUFFED WITH KALE, CRANBERRIES, AND WALNUTS

As soon as the weather turns and mounds of winter squash start appearing at the market, I find every reason to turn on the oven, steam up the windows, and make a warming autumn meal that fills the house with all kinds of good smells. This recipe is one of those reasons!

It’s not exactly a one-pot meal. It’s more like an all-in-one meal: mouth-meltingly tender roasted squash heaped with herb-scented brown rice, silky kale, and cranberries and walnuts. A splash of balsamic cuts the sweetness, and a sprinkle of feta adds some sharpness. If I was making this for my more carnivorous husband, I might be inclined to bake a strip of bacon in the oven with the squash and then crumble it over the rice. That’s the beauty of a stuffed squash: You can stuff it with just about anything.

MAKES 4 SERVINGS

2 (1 1/2-pound) acorn squashes

2 tablespoons olive oil, divided

A few pinches of kosher salt

A few grinds of black pepper

2 shallots, chopped

2 garlic cloves, chopped

1 cup uncooked brown rice, rinsed

2 1/4 cups chicken broth

2 cups chopped kale, ribs and stems removed

2 tablespoons chopped fresh sage

2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar

3/4 cup dried cranberries

1/2 cup toasted and chopped walnuts

1/4 to 1/2 cup crumbled feta cheese

Preheat the oven to 425°F.

Slice the squashes in half lengthwise, then scoop out the stringy centers and seeds until you get a nice hollow in each squash. Place them cut sides up on a large rimmed baking sheet and drizzle 1 tablespoon of the oil over them. Sprinkle the salt and pepper on top, and roast the squashes for about 40 minutes until the edges are browned and the flesh is easily pierced with a fork. When the squashes are done, keep them warm in the oven until they are ready to serve.

Meanwhile, heat a large saucepan over medium heat. Swirl in the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil, and add the shallots and garlic. Cook until the shallots start to turn translucent, 2 to 3 minutes. Stir in the rice and cook for 30 seconds to bring out its fragrance. Add the broth and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat, cover, and simmer for about 40 minutes until most of the liquid is absorbed. About 15 minutes before the rice is done, add the kale and sage right on top, and cover it again. There is no need to stir just yet, as the leaves will steam and wilt on the surface while the rice continues to cook underneath them.

When the rice is fully cooked, turn off the heat and let stand for 5 minutes. Uncover, then mix in the kale and sage and fluff with a fork. Stir in the vinegar, cranberries, and walnuts.

Remove the squashes from the oven. Heap the rice filling into each squash and top with crumbled feta.

cook’s note

If you don’t have any acorn squash on hand, try the recipe with kabocha, red kuri, delicata, or another orange-fleshed winter squash.

Flowers & Herbs

Though they seem small and insignificant, flowers and herbs truly pack an aromatic punch on the palate. I’m never without a little sprig of something, whether it’s basil blossoms to pretty up a plate or fragrant thyme to throw into a roast. After my first loves in the kitchen—garlic and onions—leafy herbs are almost always the next ingredients to make it into a recipe, as either a bold seasoning or a subtle garnish.

While most of us are familiar with the Mediterranean herbs, such as basil, rosemary, parsley, and cilantro, we tend to forget their fragrant flowers. Oftentimes they’re trimmed off the plants to promote growth (as with basil) or they don’t bloom until the end of the plant’s life (as with parsley), so we rarely see them and rarely use them. But the flowers are just as savory, spicy, or sweet as the leaves, so don’t shy away from sprinkling them into soups or scattering them across salads.

If you find yourself stuck with a bagful of stems or a hodgepodge of herbs at the end of the week (and who doesn’t, as we’re just adding a handful here and a spoonful there most of the time), read on for a few ideas on using up the rest of your bundles.

herb-infused vinegars

Herb-infused vinegars sound like something you’d buy at a fancy shop, but they couldn’t be easier (or cheaper) to make at home. I usually keep a few kinds in the kitchen (alongside my balsamic and rice vinegars) for making sauces, marinades, and dressings. They truly send salads over the top! They also make good use of the no-less-flavorful (but bizarre-to-eat) blossoms on chives and basil, especially if you grow them at home. To step up the game, use wine vinegar or champagne vinegar for your infusions. Left to steep for a couple of weeks, the blossoms will give your vinegar a lovely magenta tint.

chive blossom vinegar

In a small saucepan over medium heat, warm the vinegar. You don’t need it simmering, just warm enough to coax the fragrant oils from the chive blossoms.

Fill a jar or bottle with the blossoms, then pour the warm vinegar over them. Let steep for at least two weeks out of direct sunlight before serving.

MAKES 1 1/2 CUPS

1 1/2 cups white vinegar

1 cup packed chive blossoms

basil blossom vinegar with orange peel

In a small saucepan over medium heat, warm the vinegar. You don’t need it simmering, just warm enough to coax the fragrant oils from the basil blossoms.

Fill a jar or bottle with the blossoms and orange peel, then pour the warm vinegar over them. Let steep out of direct sunlight for at least two weeks before serving.

MAKES 1 1/2 CUPS

1 1/2 cups white vinegar

1 cup packed basil blossoms

1 (6-inch) orange peel

cook’s note

Thoroughly soak, wash, and dry the blossoms before using; little critters sometimes like to hide in the crevices. If desired, strain the vinegar once it’s fully infused.

thai basil pesto

Basil pesto is not a new thing, but Thai basil pesto is one of my favorite variations on this summertime staple. The fresh herb, fresh ginger, and fish sauce give enormous depth of flavor that works well in many other dishes besides pasta. (I especially like it as a spread for my Heirloom Tomato Galette, page 42.) If you have a beautiful bunch of flowering basil to use up, give the blossoms a whirl with the leaves. They’re just as fragrant and flavorful.

MAKES 1 CUP

2 cups packed Thai basil with flowers

1/3 cup dry-roasted peanuts

2 teaspoons fish sauce

1 1/2 tablespoons chopped ginger

3 garlic cloves

Zest and juice of 1 lime

1/4 to 1/2 cup peanut oil

Add all the ingredients (except the oil) to a food processor and pulse to combine, scraping down the sides of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Continue pulsing and add the oil in a slow, steady stream until the pesto reaches the consistency you like. Use less oil for a thick paste or more oil for a thin sauce.

nasturtium pesto

Sometimes disregarded as a weed and almost always regarded as an ornamental plant, nasturtiums (Tropaeolum majus, not to be confused with the Nasturtium genus that includes cress) can also be considered a leaf vegetable. The fast-growing vines bear circular leaves and trumpet-shaped flowers, both of which have a peppery, pungent bite due to the high concentration of mustard oils in the plant. In fact, these are the same mustard oils found in mustard seeds, horseradish root, and wasabi, giving nasturtiums natural antibiotic, antifungal, antiviral, and antibacterial properties. The mustard oils are released when the nasturtiums are crushed or chewed, thus making them taste—but not smell—intense.

If you grow nasturtiums at home or find them in the wild, pick off a few leaves and flowers for a beautiful forager’s salad. If you have enough to go around, nasturtiums add a lively heat to homemade pesto.

MAKES 1 CUP

2 cups packed nasturtium leaves

1 cup packed nasturtium flowers

1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese

1/3 cup toasted walnuts

3 garlic cloves

1/4 to 1/2 cup olive oil

Add all the ingredients (except the oil) to a food processor and pulse until crumbly, scraping down the sides of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Continue pulsing and add the oil in a steady stream until well blended.

For a thick paste that you can spread onto sandwiches and pizzas, use only 1/4 cup of oil. For a thin sauce that you can stir into pastas and soups, use a full 1/2 cup.

pickled nasturtium pods
(AKA POOR MAN’S CAPERS)

All through spring, masses of nasturtiums are in bloom, sending up brilliant trumpet-shaped flowers in a show of red, orange, yellow, pink, and peach. It’s quite a sight for the season. But as soon as the first wave of hot weather hits, the petals begin to wilt, and in their place are clusters of lightly ribbed, bright green seed pods clinging to the stems.

Like the leaves and flowers, the seed pods are peppery and spicy, but even more so. In the raw, they pack a nose-tingling punch. But bathed in vinegar, they turn pleasantly pungent, tasting a little like capers. Though I sometimes call them poor man’s capers, they have a distinct, mustardy flavor all their own. Use them how you’d normally use capers: a spoonful at a time, chopped up to add a little bite to salads, omelettes, pastas, sauces, and dressings.

MAKES 1 CUP

2 cups water

1/4 cup kosher salt

2/3 cup nasturtium seed pods

2/3 cup white vinegar

1 teaspoon sugar

1 bay leaf

Raw nasturtium seed pods are strong and bitter in flavor, so start by tempering them in a brine. Pour the water and salt into a quart-size jar and stir to dissolve the grains. (You can brine a couple of batches at the same time in the same jar.) Add the nasturtium pods and keep them submerged in the brine. To do so easily, place an open resealable plastic bag over the rim and down into the jar (use a stone to weigh it down if needed). Let stand at room temperature, out of direct sunlight, for 2 to 3 days. The nasturtium pods will turn a dull green during this period.

Drain the seeds and rinse under cold running water to remove excess salt. Set them aside until ready to use.

In a small saucepan over medium-high heat, bring the vinegar and sugar to a simmer. Stir until the sugar is dissolved, then remove from heat.

Pack the nasturtium pods into a jar, then pour the hot vinegar over them. Float the bay leaf on top, then let cool to room temperature before sealing with a lid. Allow to pickle for at least 3 days before serving. Since vinegar is a natural preservative, the pickled nasturtium pods can safely be stored at room temperature as long as the pods stay submerged in liquid. If preferred, you can also refrigerate them.

cook’s note

Hunt for the seed pods before they turn brown and brittle. Once the flowers fade, look for fresh, green, juicy seeds that haven’t fallen to the ground yet.

Left, Cilantro Jalapeño Hummus; right, Cilantro Pepita Pesto

cilantro

I’m always a happy gal when I have a bunch of cilantro that doesn’t need stemming. (Or is it destemming?) In fact, this is how you make cilantro go the extra mile if the leaves look a little tired but the stems are still crisp and healthy. Give them a good blitz in a food processor and watch the stringy stems transform into a smooth, vibrant, and flavorful puree—like these Mexican-inspired takes on Middle Eastern hummus and Italian pesto. Don’t be shy with the jalapeños; they’re more feisty than they are fiery.

cilantro jalapeño hummus

Add all the ingredients to a food processor and pulse continuously until smooth. If you prefer a thinner consistency, add the water 1 tablespoon at a time, pulse to combine, and add more water as needed.

MAKES 1 1/2 CUPS

1 (15-ounce) can chickpeas, drained and rinsed

3/4 cup packed cilantro with stems

1/4 cup olive oil

1 jalapeño pepper, chopped (remove ribs and seeds for less heat)

2 garlic cloves

1/2 teaspoon kosher salt

Zest and juice of 1 lime

1 to 4 tablespoons water (optional)

cilantro pepita pesto

In a food processor, combine the cilantro, pepitas, jalapeño, garlic, salt, lime zest, and lime juice. Pulse until a crumbly texture forms, scraping down the sides with a rubber spatula as needed. Continue pulsing and add the oil in a slow, steady stream until well blended. Add the Cotija and pulse a few more times to combine.

MAKES 1 CUP

2 cups packed cilantro with stems

1/3 cup toasted pepitas (shelled pumpkin seeds)

1 jalapeño pepper, chopped (remove ribs and seeds for less heat)

3 garlic cloves

1/4 teaspoon salt

Zest and juice of 1 lime

1/4 cup olive oil

1/3 cup crumbled Cotija cheese

chimichurri
THE WAY AN ARGENTINE MAKES IT

The stars of this tangy green sauce are parsley and garlic, and plenty of it. It hails from the Land of Silver, where it’s drizzled over the country’s famous smoky grilled meats. Chimichurri is often bastardized in American cuisine, even so far as being called “Argentinian pesto” or the “ketchup of Argentina” (which any Argentine will insist is not true). Many variations have included cilantro, chiles, or lemons, and while those are all acceptable, this recipe is pure, authentic Argentina: fresh herbs, all chopped by hand, and left to sit overnight for the flavors to marry.

Good chimichurri is never a grassy green; it may start out that way, but it truly sings when the leaves turn dull. My favorite kind of chimichurri has always been the one that sits in a metal tin at an Argentinian restaurant, all brown and murky looking, and you have no idea how long it’s been there or when it was last refilled, but it tastes amazing. Like Argentinian asado, chimichurri often enlivens a plate of roasted vegetables, baked potatoes, and scrambled eggs.

MAKES 2 CUPS

2 cups packed fresh parsley, minced

3 tablespoons minced garlic

3 tablespoons minced fresh oregano

1 1/2 tablespoons red pepper flakes

1 to 1 1/4 cups olive oil

1/4 cup red wine vinegar

In a medium bowl, combine all the ingredients. Use less oil for a chunkier texture, or more oil for a looser consistency. Decant the sauce into a jar, cover, and let stand at room temperature overnight before refrigerating. The flavor will intensify the longer it sits. Well-aged chimichurri is a deep army green with a burst of tang and spice.

“all in” herb dressing

In any given week, my fridge is usually filled with the odds and ends of several herbs I’ve used once or twice, then struggled to use again before they turned slimy. I might have a few sprigs of parsley left (though not enough for Chimichurri the Way an Argentine Makes It, page 214), a quarter bundle of basil, a stem of tarragon, a small handful of chives. With a motley crew like this, I’ll usually dump them all into what I call “All In” Herb Dressing: a freestyle version of green goddess dressing, where almost anything goes. It’s smooth, creamy, and tangy, like a lighter, brighter ranch dressing.

Don’t feel limited to just the herbs I’ve listed either; make this dressing your own with cilantro, dill, or any leafy herb that’s lingering in the fridge.

MAKES 1 1/4 CUPS

1/2 cup sour cream

1/2 cup mayonnaise

1/4 cup packed fresh parsley

1/4 cup packed fresh basil

2 tablespoons chopped tarragon

2 tablespoons chopped chives

1/2 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce

1/2 teaspoon kosher salt

1 garlic clove

Juice of 1/2 lemon

Add all of the ingredients to a blender and blend until silky smooth. Pour the dressing into a bottle or jar and refrigerate until ready to serve. If the dressing has thickened too much for your liking, thin it out a bit with a spoonful of water (or buttermilk) before serving.

cook’s note

Though I call this recipe a dressing, it also makes a creamy and delicious dip for crudités.

MARINATED FETA
with a mess of herbs

Like the “All In” Herb Dressing (page 215), this is a good way to use up those random stems of fresh herbs that are on their last legs. (If you’re like me, you’ve probably got one or two idling in the fridge right now.) I recommend at least three herbs in the mix for a more layered flavor, so throw in as many as you have. Let them commingle in the morning, and by afternoon you’ll have a creamy, savory, bite-size snack for happy hour.

MAKES 2 CUPS

1 cup olive oil

2 tablespoons chopped fresh herbs (mix and match with rosemary, thyme, sage, oregano, marjoram, savory, dill, or your favorites)

1 teaspoon black peppercorns

Zest and juice of 1 lemon

Pinch of red pepper flakes

1 (8-ounce) block feta cheese, cut into 1/2-inch cubes

In a small bowl, combine the oil, herbs, peppercorns, lemon zest, lemon juice, and red pepper flakes.

Layer the feta cubes and herbed oil in a jar, making sure the feta is fully submerged. Marinate at room temperature for 3 to 4 hours (though if you can wait, 6 to 8 hours is even better). Refrigerate any unused portion after 1 day. The oil may congeal in the cold temperature, but this will not affect the flavor; simply bring the marinated feta to room temperature before serving.

DON’T TOSS IT YET!

Once all the feta’s been eaten, use the herb-infused oil in a salad dressing or marinade—just give it a good whisk with your favorite vinegar. Depending on the vinegar used and flavor desired, a classic vinaigrette ratio is 2:1 or 3:1 (oil to vinegar).

about the author

Linda Ly is the creator, writer, and photographer of Garden Betty, an award-winning blog that celebrates the good life, from growing and preserving food to exploring and adventuring across continents. Recognized by Country Living and HGTV as the go-to source in gardening and green living, Ly gets down and dirty on her modern homestead by the sea, where she raises backyard chickens, tends a kitchen garden, and makes farm-to-fork meals. She lives in the South Bay of Los Angeles with her two pugs and her husband, Will Taylor, an image-making mastermind whose talent can be seen throughout The CSA Cookbook.

Off the homestead, they enjoy surfing, snowboarding, climbing, kayaking, and backpacking all over the great state of California and fixing up their off-grid surfside bungalow in Mexico.

Read more at www.gardenbetty.com.
